info.title: Functional School
info.description:
A trip through functional programming in Javascript using common built-in Javascript array methods such as `map` & `reduce`.

By the end, you should have an understanding of how to use array methods to manipulate semi-complex data.

Level: Intermediate
Keywords: javascript, functional
Length: 1-2 hours


<!-- @import('08/challenge-1') -->
<!-- @import('09/challenge-2') -->

pages.title: Start
pages.description:
Understanding the Data Set

Over this tutorial series, we'll be changing and working with two different data sets. It'll be a big help to first understand what the data looks like.

```json
var students = [
  {
    "title": "Relational Databases",
    "instructor": "Sean Quentin Lewis",
    "name": "Ada Lovelace",
    "score": 91,
    "grade": "A"
  },
  ...
]
```

Here we have an array of "student" objects. To get the first item in the array, you can use the array index. Array indexes start at 0.

```js
console.log(
  'first instructor', students[0].instructor
);
// first instructor Sean Quentin Lewis
```

tasks.description: Load the student data into "students.js"
actions: open('data/students.js')

tasks.description: Set `first` to the first item in the `students` array.
actions: open('00-setup.js')

set('// Welcome to CodeRoad!
import students from './data/students';

var first = ::>
')
hints: Get the first item in students using the array index

tasks.description: Set `myName` to the "name" of the first student in the list.
actions:
insert('var myName = ::>
')
hints: Get the first "name" in the students using the array index

tasks.description: Log your name to the console.

pages.onPageComplete: Now we're ready to get started with `filter`ing our data.

pages.title: Filter

tasks.description: Write a filter condition function called `isAda` that returns true only if the name matches your name: "Ada Lovelace".
actions: open('01-filter.js')

tasks.description: Set `var myData` to filter with the `isAda` function.
hints: Add a function to the `filter` call: `Array.filter(function() {})`

tasks.description: Write a filter condition called `isGoodGrade` that will filter out any "D" or "F" grades.
Set `var myBest` to your scores, excluding any grades that are "D" or "F".

pages.onPageComplete: In the next step we'll look at how to `sort` data

pages.title: Sort
pages.description:
Array -> sorted Array

Your grades are filtered down to your name and good scores - but wouldn't it be better if your best grades were displayed first, at the top? Besides, your parents rarely read anything through.

You can use the array method `sort` to arrange your data. Let's see how it works.

```js
['c', 'b', 'a'].sort();
//> ['a', 'b', 'c']

[3, 2, 1].sort();
//> [1, 2, 3]
```

But what about sorting scores inside of an object?

```js
[{a: 3}, {a: 1}, {a: 2}].sort();
//> [{a: 3}, {a: 1}, {a: 2}]
```

That didn't work. Instead, you can write a custom `compareScore` function.

A sort function takes two params, and compares the first to the second. It should return values saying where the second value should go in the array:

  * -1 : sort to a lower index (front)
  * 1 : sort to a higher index (back)
  * 0 : stay the same

Alright, now time to sort your best grades to the top.

First you'll need to write a sort condition function called `compareScore`.

tasks.description: load `myBest`
actions: open('data/myBest.js')

tasks.description: `compareScore` should return 1 if the first score is less than the second
actions: open('02-sort.js')

tasks.description: `compareScore` should return -1 if the first score is more than the second
hints: set the second case to `b.score < a.score`

tasks.description: `compareScore` should return 0 if the first score is the same as the second
hints: no case is necessary, use the `default` case

tasks.description: Set `mySorted` to the result of `myBest` sorted by `compareScore`
actions:
insert('// use the compare function to sort myBest
var mySorted = myBest::>
')

pages.onPageComplete: In the next step we'll look at changing data with `map`

pages.title: Map

tasks.description: load "myData"
actions: open('data/myData.js')

tasks.description: Make a function `changeGrade` that takes student data and changes all grades to "A"s.
actions: open('03-map.js')

tasks.description: Map over the `myData` with the `changeGrade` function. Set `myChanged` to the result.

Hold up. An A in "Data Science" class looks way to suspicious. Your parents might catch on to your cheating.

Let's go back to `myData` and instead increment each score by 12 points.
Wait. Now you're getting 105 in "Algorithm Design" class. Fix `increaseScore` so that the maximum score is 95. That should be less suspicious.

One more problem. Now the scores don't match the grades. you have 95 score in "3D Computer Graphics", but only a "B" grade. Set `myFixed` as the result of using the `getGrade` function to set grades according to their new scores.
hints: change `getGrade` to take a `student` param instead of `score`
change the grade and return the `student`

tasks.description: Check to make sure everything is working. Set `scoresAndGrades` to an array of scores and grades only.
hints: use `map` to return only the "score" & "grade" fields
map with a function with a parameter, call it "student"

pages.onPageComplete: In the next step we'll compare `map` with `forEach`

pages.title: forEach

tasks.description: load "myFixed"
actions: open('data/myFixed.js')

tasks.description: Use `forEach` to log out your report card to the console
actions: open('04-forEach.js')

tasks.description: Add a second parameter to `logCourseWithIndex` called `index`. Then call the function with `myFixed.forEach`.
hints: Array methods can take more than one parameter

tasks.description: Add a third parameter called `array` to `logCourseWithIndexAndArray`, then call the function with `myFixed.forEach`.
hints: Array methods can take more than one parameter

tasks.description:
What??? Suddenly Your data has all disappeared!

It seems `myFixed` relies on a chain of methods.

```js
myFixed = students
    .filter(isAda)
    .sort(compareScore)
    .map(increaseScore)
    .map(getGrade)
    .forEach(logCourseWithIndexAndArray)
```

This is why side-effects are dangerous. Students data must have changed, and now all of your transformations are effected.

pages.onPageComplete: Something strange is going on. In the next step we'll try to `find` your data.

tasks.description: load "students" data
actions: open('data/students2.js')

use `otherStudents.indexOf(x) === -1` to find what doesn't match

tasks.description: `filter` down to students without known names

pages.onPageComplete: Very strange. In the next step, let's find out who wants revenge, and give it to him!

pages.title: concat

tasks.description: load "courses"
actions: open('data/courses2.js')

tasks.description: First, test out `flatten` on the `flattenedArray`
actions: open('06-concat.js')

tasks.description:
Now `map` over the courses array, and `map` over the students array inside of it.
Return the fields:

  * title
  * instructor
  * name
  * grade
  * score
Use `flatten` to put all data into a single array. Set `students` to the result.
Use the `suspects` array to `filter` to only "Hack Kerr"'s data

You just thought of two more suspects! Make a new variable called `newSuspects` and add it above `suspects`.

```js
var newSuspects = ['Albert Gonzalez', 'Kevin Mitnick'];
```

`concat` the `newSuspects` onto the `suspects` list.

pages.onPageComplete: In the next step, we'll look at using one of the most powerful methods: `reduce`

pages.title: reduce

tasks.description: Use `reduce` to sum the numbers in the `practice` array
actions: open('07-reduce.js')
hints: with only numbers, the initialValue defaults to 0

tasks.description:
Not all reduce functions are so easy. `reduce` is a little more difficult to master.

`map` over each course and use `reduce` to calculate the class averages for each class. Set `averages` to the resulting array of all class averages.
load suspectData
actions: open('data/suspectData.js')

tasks.description: `reduce` to an array of suspect scores from the `suspectData` we collected previously.
actions: open('07-reduce.js')
hints: if the name is new, push an object with name & scores: `{ name: '', scores: [42]}`
you can concat the scores onto an array: `[].concat(next.score)`
if the name is already in the list, just add the `next.score`

tasks.description:
`map` over suspect data to find the `"difference"` from subtracting the students score from the average score. Add this to `suspectScores` using the key `difference`. The resulting array should look like this:
```js
[{
  name: 'suspectName',
  scores: [50, 65, 75 ...],
  difference: 15
}]
```
hints: You may want to use a second param: `index`
To get a sum, start your `reduce` function at 0

tasks.description:
`reduce` down to likely suspect names by filtering with the `isCheater` function.

This could be done with a `filter` & `map`, but it is simpler to just use one `reduce`.
It looks like we have a likely suspect.
actions:
insert('console.log(likelySuspects);
')
